item.title: Vladimir Putin Won’t Expel U.S. Diplomats as Russian Foreign Minister Urged
item.description: In a head-spinning turn, Mr. Putin decided against actions recommended just hours earlier by Sergey V. Lavrov in response to American sanctions and expulsions.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Greek Ambassador to Brazil Is Feared Dead, in a Possible Homicide
item.media:description: Greece’s ambassador to Brazil, Kyriakos Amiridis, in May, after presenting his credentials in Brasília.
item.media:credit: Marcos Correa/Brazilian Presidency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A body that might be that of Ambassador Kyriakos Amiridis, who has been missing for days, was found outside Rio de Janeiro in a car he had rented.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA and ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Theresa May Scolds Kerry for Focus on Israel Settlements
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain, left, has been trying to make inroads with the incoming Trump administration.
item.description: The comments from the British leader, who has been trying to make inroads with the incoming Trump administration, represented an extraordinary public rebuke.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Syrian Refugees on the War, Their Camp, and Your Questions
item.description: In the fall, we visited one of the largest Syrian refugee camps in the world while live on Facebook. Here’s what we heard from the refugees and from you.
item.dc:creator: DEBORAH ACOSTA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: In ‘Red’ and ‘Blue’ Israel, Separate Lives and Divergent Narratives
item.media:description: Palestinian workers at a construction site in the Israeli settlement of Efrat, in the occupied West Bank, on Thursday.
item.description: The reactions to international criticism of Israeli settlements made clear that Israelis are just as polarized as Americans.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Along Mosul’s Front Line, Desperate Civilians and Dug-In Troops and Fighters
item.media:description: A fire set by the Islamic State at oil fields south of Mosul.
item.description: Witnessing firsthand this volatile zone, first with the Iraqi Army and then with units of the Iraqi Federal Police.
item.dc:creator: Photographs and Text by TYLER HICKS

item.title: In a Brutal Year in Venezuela, Even Crime Fighters Are Killers
item.media:description: A funeral procession in Capaya, Venezuela, for men killed after raids by the security forces.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The deaths of people arrested in anti-crime raids point to an alarming aspect in the wave of violence gripping the nation.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Argentine Court Reopens Investigation of Ex-President in ’94 Bomb Case
item.media:description: An Argentine court reopened a criminal complaint on Thursday that accuses former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of a cover-up.
item.description: A court reopened a criminal complaint that accuses former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of a cover-up in connection with the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI

item.title: China Says It Will Prosecute Ex-Security Official in Bribery Case
item.description: Ma Jian, a former vice minister of the Ministry of State Security, took bribes and used his position to help a relative, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China

item.title: Catholic Churches in China Should Be Independent of Vatican, Official Says
item.media:description: Sunday Mass in the state-approved Xuanwumen Catholic Church in Beijing on Dec. 4.
item.description: The nationalistic remarks in Beijing came as China was negotiating a possible deal to improve ties with the Vatican.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: The Saturday Profile: After Building a Media Empire, What’s Next? Lifting One Million From Poverty
item.media:description: Ronnie Screwvala in 2013. A wealthy entrepreneur, he has committed himself to elevating the people of rural India.
item.description: An Indian couple use huge profits from a deal with Disney to finance a nonprofit that aims to help a million villagers build better lives.
item.dc:creator: PERRY GARFINKEL

item.title: What in the World: Six Feet Across and Full of Peril: England’s Killer Creek
item.media:description: The Bolton Strid is narrow and deep, a powerful wedge of water racing through a crevasse riddled with underwater caves and overhangs.
item.media:credit: Andy Haslam for The New York Times
item.description: The Bolton Strid burbles among moss-covered stones in Yorkshire. But this scenic stretch of river, deceptively deep and riddled with caves, is deadly.
item.dc:creator: DES SHOE

item.title: Syrian Cease-Fire Appears to Be Holding, for Now
item.media:description: Ruined buildings in Douma, Syria, a rebel-held area near Damascus, on Friday.
item.description: Minor clashes were reported in the country, though the largest rebel group denied it was a part of the deal brokered by Russia, Turkey and Syria’s government.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere: Mongolia, With Deep Ties to Dalai Lama, Turns From Him Toward China
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama after addressing a crowd in Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia, in November. China had objected to his visit.
item.description: The country appeared to be bowing to pressure from Beijing after the spiritual leader’s visit, but his trip prompted speculation that his successor might be born there.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Trilobites: Cheetahs in Danger of Extinction, Researchers Say
item.media:description: A cheetah cub with its mother in the Maasai Mara National Reserve in Kenya. Researchers called for the International Union for Conservation of Nature to change the cheetah’s status from vulnerable to endangered.
item.description: A drop in their numbers has prompted an international team to call for changing the animal’s status from vulnerable to endangered.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
International Union for Conservation of Nature

item.title: Toga Parties, Gangsters and Near-Death Experiences: 27 Years With The Times
item.media:description: Trying various gas masks with Malcolm Browne, left, and Philip Shenon, right, in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, in January 1991.
item.description: Walter Baranger reflects on his decades-long career managing logistics and communications for The Times’s far-flung bureaus.
item.dc:creator: WALTER BARANGER

item.title: ‘Comfort Woman’ Statue Reinstated Near Japan Consulate in South Korea
item.media:description: Protesters in Busan, South Korea, on Wednesday shielding a bronze statue installed as a reminder of sexual slavery during World War II. Soon removed by the police, the statue was allowed to return on Friday.
item.media:credit: Yonghap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The consulate, in the city of Busan, had objected to the statue, meant to represent women forced into sexual slavery by Japan in World War II.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Spies vs. Spies: A Cold War Regularity That Never Quite Cooled
item.media:description: Ryan C. Fogle was asked to leave Russia in 2013 after he was caught carrying two wigs, $130,000 in cash and a recruitment letter offering “up to $1 million a year for long-term cooperation.”
item.description: President Obama’s expulsion of 35 diplomats as retaliation for Russian hacking during the election is not the first such order by either country.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Uncertainty Over New Chinese Law Rattles Foreign Nonprofits
item.media:description: A Greenpeace protest near Beijing in 2009. A new law in China is raising concern among thousands of nongovernmental organizations about their ability to continue their work in the new year.
item.description: The law regulating NGOs remains opaque, and groups working on politically sensitive issues like human rights and legal reform are jittery about their future.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China

item.title: How Russia Recruited Elite Hackers for Its Cyberwar
item.media:description: An internet security firm in Moscow. While much about Russia’s cyberwarfare program is shrouded in secrecy, details of the government’s effort to recruit programmers in the months before the American presidential election shed light on the Kremlin’s plan to create teams of computer hackers.
item.description: The government scouted a wide range of civilian programmers in recent years, even criminals, while expanding its cyberwarfare abilities.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: The Interpreter: The Two-State Solution: What It Is and Why It Hasn’t Happened
item.media:description: A construction site in the Israeli settlement of Efrat in the West Bank.
item.description: The two-state solution has for decades been the primary focus of efforts to achieve peace in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Here’s a basic guide.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Facebook’s Safety Check, Now Automated, Turns a Firecracker Into an Explosion
item.media:description: In June, Facebook began rolling out automated, “community-generated” Safety Checks.
item.description: The social network automatically linked to a bogus article about an “explosion” in Thailand and appeared to conflate it with a 2015 bombing.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Germany Releases Tunisian Held in Connection With Berlin Attack
item.description: Further investigation showed the 40-year-old had not been in contact with the man who drove a truck into a Christmas fair, killing 12, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Praise for Kerry’s Israel Speech in Arab World, but Shrugs, Too
item.media:description: In Jerusalem on Thursday, tourists took pictures of the Old City.
item.description: Arab governments welcomed the secretary of state’s harsh words for the Israeli government, but are less focused on Palestinians than they once were.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Russia Finds No Signs of Explosion in Black Sea Plane Crash
item.description: While the authorities stressed that they considered a terrorist attack unlikely, they made clear on Thursday that they were leaving open the possibility.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Jiayuguan Journal: As Interest Grows in Great Walls, an Ancient Chinese Fortress Beckons
item.media:description: Tourists inside the Jiayuguan fort in Jiayuguan, Gansu Province, China. The westernmost point of the Ming-era Great Wall for over 600 years, Jiayuguan has long been overshadowed by portions of the wall outside Beijing. Local officials are hoping to change that.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: With politics and pop culture bringing walls into the global conversation, officials hope to grow interest in Jiayuguan, a remote fort in the Gobi Desert.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: China Says 5 Killed in Attack at Communist Party Office in Xinjiang
item.description: Assailants killed an official and a guard before being shot by the police, the authorities said, but advocates for minority Uighurs raised doubts about the account.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: New Cease-Fire Begins in Syria, but Violations Are Reported Within Hours
item.description: Many previous cease-fire agreements have failed, but the dynamics have changed since pro-government forces fully retook Aleppo.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Sinosphere: Shanghai’s Move to Curb International Programs in Schools Worries Parents
item.media:description: Wu Dongmei, right, is worried that the international school program her 14-year-old son, Wu Zhengxuan, is enrolled in might be replaced by Shanghai’s education commission.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: A city commission has accused private schools of replacing official curriculums, which stress political ideology, with others infringing on “China’s education sovereignty.”
item.dc:creator: KAROLINE KAN

item.title: Sinosphere: China Warmly Welcomes a Giant Rooster With Trumpian Characteristics
item.media:description: A giant rooster sculpture resembling President-elect Donald J. Trump outside a shopping mall in Taiyuan, China. The statue was built to celebrate the coming Year of the Rooster in the Chinese lunar calendar.
item.description: The statue of a bird with big hair, which stands more than two stories tall, was built to celebrate the Year of the Rooster in the Chinese lunar calendar.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: A Brother’s Crimes and a Sister’s Betrayal Make ‘Judas’ a Dutch Best Seller
item.media:description: Willem Holleeder, right, and Cor van Hout, in Amsterdam in 1987 before the start of their trial for the kidnapping of the beer tycoon Alfred Heineken.
item.description: The Dutch author Astrid Holleeder, who will soon testify against her brother Willem in court, describes in chilling detail the mafia-style hold he had on others.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: John Kerry and Israel: Too Little and Too Late
item.media:description: John Kerry speaking at the State Department on Wednesday.
item.description: Perhaps years of sustained pressure would have limited Benjamin Netanyahu’s appetite for settlement expansion. Or perhaps not.
item.dc:creator: RASHID KHALIDI

item.title: Editorial: President Obama Punishes Russia, at Last
item.media:description: President Obama and President Putin in 2015.
item.description: No, Mr. Trump, Americans are not going to forget about Russian hacking.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: 2016: Worst. Year. Ever?
item.description: And you thought this was bad. History has plenty more where this one came from.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES NEVIN

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
